The fate of a major ecosystem service may then hinge disproportion- ately on the fate of individual, large-sized species—a finding with profound consequences for conservation priorities. Overall, we note that our general approach of estimating functional contributions of decomposer taxa as differences in mass among dung pats to which they had vs. lacked access relies on the explicit assumption that relevant taxa were present across sites. For pat- dwelling dung beetles in the genus Aphodius, this assumption was verified through direct sampling of five bait pats (see above and Appendix B). Q18_SurveyNotes: Talk about development threshold in discussion, under which wild populations can sustain without stocking, but authors don't evaluate this threshold level. Negative (and nonlinear) relationship between lakeshore development and density/survivorship with juvenile and adult fish, positive (nonlinear, asymptotes) relationship between lakeshore development and probability of stocking. Checked "population growth" in Q12 because seemed close enough to lakeshore development. The point of this paper is that increased lakeshore development creates dependence on DNR fish stocking to support recreational ES of system (wild fish in lake have lower survival rate). Paper also related lakeshore development to cost and profits the state takes in, but did not record that in Q12 as it's more social-science than ecology (but this paper aims to do full socio-economic assessment).
Round1_Comments: Attempts to link human driver (lakeshore development) to fisheries ES
